raw_text:
Music mogul Fuller sells company
 
 Pop Idol supremo Simon Fuller has sold his 19 Entertainment company to an US entrepreneur in a $156m (£81.5m) deal.
 
 Robert Sillerman's Sports Entertainment Enterprises, which is to be renamed CFX, recently also bought an 85% share in the estate of Elvis Presley. Mr Fuller has been appointed to the CFX board and will plan and implement the company's creative strategy. The 19 firm handles a roster of music artists, TV shows and PR strategies for stars including the Beckhams. The deal sees Mr Fuller receive £64.5m in cash and about 1.9 million shares in Sports Entertainment. There will also be a further £19.2m in either cash or stocks by the end of the financial year in June. Mr Fuller has signed a long-term agreement with the company which will see him continue to expand and develop entertainment brands. He said: "This is a hugely exciting new partnership for myself and 19 Entertainment.
 
 "CKX will provide 19 with a powerful platform for global growth and allow us to fully take advantage of all the amazing opportunities that lie ahead. I cannot wait to get started."
 
 Mr Fuller was the creative drive behind Pop Idol and its US offspring American Idol. 19 Management runs the careers of many of its successful contestants including Will Young, Gareth Gates and Kelly Clarkson. The company was set up 15 years ago by Mr Fuller, taking the name from his first successful single - 19 by Paul Hardcastle. Fuller was the driving force behind the Spice Girls phenomenon, using canny marketing and catchy pop songs to secure their place as the most lucrative girl group in history. He then put together S Club 7, who had their own TV show as well as a music career. Mr Sillerman's deal to buy the Presley estate sees him control the operation of Graceland, as well as money from the late star's music and films. Presley's daughter Lisa Marie retains possession of Graceland and many of her father's "personal effects".
llama3.2:1b: Simon Fuller has sold his 19 Entertainment company to US entrepreneur Robert Sillerman for $156 million (£81.5m).
He will continue to serve on the CFX board, which now handles music artists, TV shows, and PR strategies for stars such as the Beckhams.
The deal includes a cash payment of £64.5m and approximately 1.9 million shares in Sports Entertainment.
Fuller also receives £19.2m by June's end, contingent on either cash or stock.
He has signed a long-term agreement with CFX, expanding and developing entertainment brands, including his role as creative director for the company.
llama3.2:3b: Simon Fuller has sold his 19 Entertainment company to US entrepreneur Robert Sillerman for $156m.
Mr Fuller will remain on the CFX board, overseeing creative strategy.
He received £64.5m in cash and shares, with further £19.2m expected by year end.
gemma2:2b: Simon Fuller has sold his 19 Entertainment company to Robert Sillerman's Sports Entertainment Enterprises for $156 million.
Fuller will remain involved with the company, serving as creative director and shaping its strategy.
The deal includes cash payment of £64.5 million and a share in the new company CFX.
Fuller's legacy includes Pop Idol and American Idol and he is now setting up a long-term partnership to expand entertainment brands globally.
Sillerman also purchased an 85% stake in Elvis Presley’s estate, including Graceland.
Presley's daughter Lisa Marie retains ownership of some personal items from her father.
